questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic feature of Meniere's disease?

choices.text: Progressive unilateral hearing loss with gradual onset
Episodic vertigo with fluctuating hearing loss and tinnitus
Sudden onset of unilateral hearing loss without vertigo
Persistent vertigo with stable hearing loss and no tinnitus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Episodic vertigo with fluctuating hearing loss and tinnitus

 

Explanation:

Meniere’s disease is most characterised by episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and tinnitus.

 

Meniere’s disease/Endolymphatic hydrops:

  • An inner ear disorder is characterised by the excessive buildup of endolymph fluid.
  • Age/Sex: Typically affects individuals aged 35-60, with a higher prevalence in males.
  • Cardinal Symptoms:

Vertigo
  • Episodic with sudden onset
  • Attacks occur in clusters, interspersed with periods of remission accompanied by nausea, vomiting, ataxia & nystagmus.
  • Loud noises might trigger vertigo due to the Tullio phenomenon.

Hearing Loss
  • Fluctuating hearing loss may improve between attacks but may progressively worsen over time, with some degree of permanent hearing loss.
  • Sensorineural hearing loss initially affecting lower frequencies.
  • Patients might experience distorted hearing or Diplacusis

Tinnitus
  • Low-pitched & Roaring type
  • It can be aggravated during acute attacks and might persist during periods of remission

Aural Fullness

Fluctuates & may vary in intensity

Emotional Impact

The recurrent nature of symptoms can lead to emotional stress and apprehension about future attacks, contributing to overall distress.

Variants of Meniers’s disease:

  • Cochlear Hydrops: Only cochlear symptoms are present initially; vertigo develops later.
  • Vestibular Hydrops: Episodic vertigo without cochlear symptoms
  • Drop Attacks (Tumarkin’s Crisis): Sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness & without vertigo/fluctuations in hearing loss.
  • Lermoyez Syndrome: Hearing loss followed by vertigo, with hearing recovery during vertigo.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. Which of the following mechanisms is associated with the pathogenesis of this condition?

choices.text: Dilatation of the internal auditory artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Defective absorption of endolymph

 

Explanation:

The given scenario is suggestive of Meniere’s disease, which is primarily associated with increased endolymph volume within the inner ear resulting from defective absorption/increased production of endolymph leading to increased endolymphatic pressure, which manifests as vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness.

 

Etiopathogenesis of Meniere’s disease:

Aetiology:

  • Increased Endolymph Volume (Option A)
  • Defective Absorption (Option B)
  • Vasomotor Disturbances: Sympathetic overactivity causing spasms in the internal auditory artery (Option C) may disrupt cochlear or vestibular function, leading to vertigo and hearing loss.
  • Allergy: Allergic reactions may cause the inner ear to produce excess endolymph. Many patients with Meniere’s disease have related allergies.
  • Sodium and Water Retention: Excess fluid retention can exacerbate endolymphatic hydrops, so reducing salt intake is recommended.
  • Hypothyroidism (Option D): A small percentage of cases are linked to hypothyroidism and can improve with thyroid replacement therapy.
  • Autoimmune and Viral Factors (Herpes family)

 

Pathology:

  • Meniere’s disease is characterised by distension of the endolymphatic system, particularly affecting the cochlear duct (scala media) and saccule, with possible involvement of the utricle and semicircular canals.
  • The cochlear duct can expand, pushing the Reissner's membrane into the scala vestibuli, potentially leading to the rupture of this membrane and mixing of perilymph with endolymph causing the classic symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent vertigo, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in his left ear, along with progressive hearing loss. He is diagnosed with Meniere’s disease, and audiometric testing is performed. Which part of the cochlea and what frequency range is typically affected first?

choices.text: Apical turn of the cochlea is affected causing high-frequency hearing loss
Basal turn of the cochlea is affected causing low-frequency hearing loss
Apical turn of the cochlea is affected causing low-frequency hearing loss
Basal turn of the cochlea is affected causing high-frequency hearing loss

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Apical turn of the cochlea is affected causing low-frequency hearing loss.

 

Explanation:

  • In Meniere’s disease, low-frequency hearing is typically affected first. This is due to the involvement of the apical turn of the cochlea, which is responsible for detecting lower frequencies.
  • Early stages of the disease often present with a rising audiogram pattern, with hearing loss predominantly affecting lower frequencies. As the disease progresses, higher frequencies may also become involved, leading to a more complex audiometric profile.

Audiometry Findings:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss (No AB Gap) initially affecting lower frequencies and can also involve higher frequencies in later stages.
  • Upsloping Type
  • The curve becomes flat/falling type in later stages once higher frequencies get affected.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient is evaluated for symptoms of recurrent vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. After a comprehensive assessment, which diagnostic test is most definitive for confirming Meniere’s disease?​​​
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Electrocochleography

 

Explanation:

Electrocochleography is useful for diagnosing Meniere’s disease due to its ability to show an elevated summating potential to action potential ratio. While tests like pure tone audiometry and the glycerol test provide supportive information, electrocochleography offers specific diagnostic criteria.

Investigations of Meniere’s Disease

Pure Tone Audiometry
  • Measures hearing sensitivity across various frequencies.
  • Sensorineural hearing loss affects lower frequencies, resulting in a rising audiogram curve.

Speech Audiometry
  • Assesses the ability to understand and discriminate speech.
  • Scores typically range from 55%-85% between attacks but worsen significantly during and immediately after an attack, with normal scores (90%-100%) in unaffected periods.

Special Audiometric Tests
  • Help differentiate Cochlear from Retrocochlear lesions
  • Recruitment Test: Positive in Meniere’s disease, indicating increased sensitivity to sound.
  • Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI) Test: Scores greater than 70% in about two-thirds of Meniere’s patients (normal score is 15%).
  • Tone Decay Test: Normally shows less than 20 dB decay, indicating a cochlear issue.

Electrocochleography

(Diagnostic)
  • Measures the electrical potentials from the inner ear in response to sound.
  • In normal ears, the summating potential (SP) to action potential (AP) ratio is around 30%, while in Meniere’s disease, it is >30%.

Caloric Test
  • Assesses the function of the vestibular system by irrigating the ear canal with warm or cold water.
  • Typically, it shows reduced response on the affected side in about 75% of cases.

Glycerol Test
  • Evaluates the effect of glycerol in reducing endolymphatic pressure.
  • A positive result is indicated by:
    • 10 dB improvement in two or more adjacent octaves
    • 10% increase in speech discrimination score.
    • Improvement in tinnitus and ear fullness.

questions.text: In MRI with gadolinium contrast for Meniere’s disease, which of the following findings is typical?

choices.text: Gadolinium in scala vestibuli & absent in scala tympani
Gadolinium is present in all three compartments
Gadolinium in the cochlear duct only

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Gadolinium is present in all three compartments

 

Explanation:

In Meniere’s disease, gadolinium contrast typically shows up in all cochlear compartments (scala vestibuli, scala tympani, and scala media) due to the rupture of the Reissner's membrane, allowing gadolinium to mix with the endolymph.

 

MRI with Gadolinium Contrast in Meniere’s Disease:

  • Gadolinium-based contrast agents in MRI differentiate between perilymphatic and endolymphatic spaces, aiding in the diagnosis of endolymphatic hydrops, a hallmark of Meniere’s disease.
  • Gadolinium Injection: Administered either intravenously 4 hours before MRI or intratympanically 24 hours before the scan.
  • Normal Findings:
    • In healthy ears, gadolinium loads into the perilymphatic space but does not enter the endolymph.
    • In Meniere’s, gadolinium is present in all three compartments due to the rupture of Reissner’s membrane.
  • Diagnostic Threshold: Endolymphatic space enlargement > 33% is considered abnormal

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with vertigo triggered by loud noises. His medical history includes a surgical fenestration for a middle ear condition. Audiometric tests are within normal limits, but vestibular testing reveals abnormal pressure responses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tullio Phenomenon

Explanation:

  • Tullio phenomenon is characterised by vertigo, dizziness, or imbalance triggered by loud sounds.
  • This occurs due to an abnormal third window effect in the inner ear, which could be caused by congenital conditions, trauma, or a surgical procedure like fenestration.
  • The pressure changes from sound waves affect the balance organs, particularly the semicircular canals, causing vertigo.

Hennebert’s sign (Option A) refers to vertigo or nystagmus induced by pressure changes in the ear without an underlying middle ear infection. It is seen in conditions like syphilis or Meniere’s disease, where pressure on the inner ear (e.g., via the Valsalva manoeuvre) provokes balance disturbances.

Lhermitte’s sign (Option C) is an electric shock-like sensation that travels down the spine and into the limbs when the neck is flexed. It is commonly associated with multiple sclerosis or cervical cord compression.

Meniere’s disease (Option D) involves episodic vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and a sense of fullness in the ear. It results from excess fluid buildup in the inner ear, affecting both hearing and balance.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo lasting several hours, associated with fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness in one ear. The symptoms have progressively worsened, and episodes are unpredictable. What is the first line of management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Low-salt diet and diuretics

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of Meniere’s disease, in which the first-line treatment includes lifestyle changes, such as a low-sodium diet to reduce fluid retention and diuretics like furosemide to decrease endolymphatic fluid pressure.
  • More invasive treatments like intratympanic gentamicin (Option A) are reserved for severe cases.
  • Vestibular rehabilitation therapy (Option C) is useful for long-term balance but not as an initial treatment.

Endolymphatic sac surgery (Option D) is considered a last resort when other treatments fail.

Management of Meniere's disease

Treatment Category

Explanation

Lifestyle Modifications
  • Low-salt diet
  • Caffeine, alcohol, nicotine avoidance
  • Stress management (yoga, relaxation exercises)
  • Hydration

Medications
  • Diuretics (e.g., furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide): Decreases fluid buildup in the inner ear
  • Vestibular sedatives (e.g., prochlorperazine): Controls symptoms of vertigo and nausea during acute attacks.
  • Betahistine (Vertin): Acts as a vasodilator to improve blood flow to the inner ear, potentially reducing vertigo.
  • Antihistamines (e.g., Meclizine): Provides symptomatic relief for vertigo.

Intratympanic Injections
  • Gentamicin: Used in refractory cases to destroy vestibular hair cells and reduce vertigo.
  • Corticosteroids: Reduces inflammation in the inner ear, potentially alleviating symptoms.

Surgical Options
  • Endolymphatic sac decompression: Decreases fluid pressure within the endolymphatic system
  • Vestibular nerve section: Severing the vestibular nerve to relieve vertigo while preserving hearing (in severe cases).
  • Labyrinthectomy: Complete destruction of the balance organs (last resort, leads to complete hearing loss).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with Ménière's disease has severe, recurrent vertigo despite conservative treatments. Her ENT specialist recommends a surgical procedure to reduce vertigo attacks while aiming to preserve her hearing. Which surgical procedure is most appropriate for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endolymphatic sac decompression

Explanation:
Endolymphatic sac decompression is typically considered when conservative and medical treatments fail. It aims to relieve fluid pressure by decompressing the endolymphatic sac while preserving hearing.

Surgical management of Meniere's disease

Procedure

Description

Purpose

Decompression of the Endolymphatic Sac

Reduces pressure in the endolymphatic system by decompressing the sac.

Controls vertigo while preserving hearing.

Endolymphatic Shunt Operation

A tube is placed to connect the endolymphatic sac with the subarachnoid space to drain excess endolymph.

Sacculotomy (Fick's Operation)

A needle is used to puncture the saccule through the stapes footplate to decompress it.

Cody's Tack Procedure

A stainless steel tack is placed through the stapes footplate to allow periodic decompression of the saccule.

Selective Section of the Vestibular Nerve

(Option B)

The vestibular nerve is cut while preserving the cochlear nerve to control vertigo.

Generally, it preserves hearing but possesses the risk of hearing loss.

Labyrinthectomy
(Option C)

Removal of the affected labyrinth leads to complete hearing loss on that side but effective control of vertigo.

Controls vertigo while hearing is significantly impaired.

Intermittent Low-Pressure Pulse Therapy (Meniett Device Therapy) (Option D):

  • This is the non-invasive approach used to deliver intermittent positive pressure waves to inner ear fluids via a ventilation tube inserted through the tympanic membrane, aimed at reducing endolymph pressure.
  • It alleviates vertigo, tinnitus, and ear fullness and improves hearing.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo but has no reported hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness. Diagnostic tests reveal no abnormalities in the cochlea or hearing function. What is the most likely diagnosis among the variants of Meniere’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vestibular Hydrops

Explanation:
The given scenario is most likely Vestibular Hydrops, as it involves vertigo without cochlear symptoms.

 

Variants of Meniere’s disease

Variant

Description

Pathophysiology

Cochlear Hydrops

Symptoms primarily involve the cochlea: fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and fullness, but no vertigo.

Increased fluid pressure confined to the cochlea, often due to a blockage at the ductus reuniens.

Vestibular Hydrops

Presents with episodic vertigo while cochlear function remains normal (no hearing loss, tinnitus, or fullness).

Fluid pressure affects the vestibular structures, particularly the saccule and utricle, sparing cochlear function.

Tumarkin’s Otolithic Crisis

Sudden"drop attacks" without loss of consciousness and no vertigo or hearing loss

Deformation of otolith membrane of the utricle or saccule due to change in endolymphatic pressure

Lermoyez Syndrome

Symptoms of Meniere’s are seen in reverse order—progressive hearing loss followed by vertigo.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane, difficulty swallowing, and hoarseness. Examination reveals glossopharyngeal nerve involvement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glomus Jugulare

 

Explanation:

The involvement of the glossopharyngeal nerve, combined with otoscopic findings of a reddish mass and pulsatile tinnitus, indicates a Glomus Jugulare tumour.

 

Type

Glomus Tympanicum
(Option A)

Glomus Jugulare
(Option B)

Location

Tumours arise from the promontory of the middle ear.

Tumours originate from the dome of the jugular bulb and can extend into the middle ear and surrounding structures.

Manifestations

Pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane.

Pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and may involve multiple cranial nerves (IX, X, XI)

Otoscopy findings
  • Reddish, pulsatile mass behind the tympanic membrane.
  • This may lead to conductive hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in the ear.

Fig: Glomus Tympanicum
  • Reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane, often pulsatile.
  • It is associated with neurological symptoms due to cranial nerve involvement, including glossopharyngeal nerve involvement.


Fig: Glomus Jugular

Glomus Vagale (Option C) tumours originate from the vagal nerve and are typically found in the neck. Symptoms relate to vagal nerve dysfunction, such as voice changes and difficulty swallowing.

 

Glomus Caroticum (Option D) tumour originates from carotid bifurcation and presents with a palpable neck mass and symptoms related to carotid body involvement such as pulsatile mass, pain, dysphagia, hoarseness, and potential hypertension due to altered carotid body function.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with progressive conductive hearing loss in her left ear over the past year, accompanied by a sensation of fullness, occasional tinnitus, and a recently discovered pulsating mass behind the left tympanic membrane. What is the investigation of choice for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Contrast-enhanced CT scan

 

Explanation:

The given scenario is suggestive of glomus tumor or paraganglioma in which Contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) is the investigation of choice.

Investigations of Glomus Tumour

CT scan

(Option A)
  • CECT (contrast-enhanced computed tomography) is the investigation of choice to distinguish between glomus tympanicum and glomus jugulare tumours and to differentiate them from an aberrant carotid artery, a high jugular bulb, or a dehiscent jugular bulb.
  • Phelps sign: On the normal side, the carotico-jugular spine (a dense bone structure between the jugular and mastoid) is intact. On the affected side, erosion of the carotico-jugular spine is observed.

CT shows enlargement of the left jugular foramen with bone erosion (arrow)

MRI scan

(Option B)
  • It demonstrates the extent of the tumour within the soft tissue.
  • Salt and pepper sign: Microhemorrhages within the tumour are visualized as white and gray dots on MRI, resulting in a "salt-and-pepper" appearance.

MRI shows a well-defned mass (arrow) in the left jugular foramen. The mass shows a "salt and pepper appearance,

Angiography

(Option D)

It is essential when CT indicates involvement of the jugular bulb, carotid artery, or intradural extension. It also aids in identifying additional glomus tumors, locating feeding vessels, and guiding embolization.

Brain Perfusion and Flow Studies

  • These are essential if the tumor compresses the internal carotid artery.
  • They assess brain perfusion, contralateral carotid artery function, and may involve xenon blood flow and isotope studies to gauge stroke risk and the need for artery replacement.

Biopsy

(Option C)
  • Histopathological studies show the Zell Ballen pattern, where epithelioid chief cells and sustentacular supporting cells form clusters (Zell Ballen) encircled by extensive vascular sinusoids.

                     Fig: Zell Ballen Appearance of Glomus Tumor

  • Preoperative biopsy of the tumour is not performed due to the risk of profuse bleeding from its highly vascular thin-walled blood sinusoids and potential injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with worsening right ear hearing loss and tinnitus resembling a heartbeat for 6 months. Examination reveals a pulsatile neck mass and a red, bulging tympanic membrane. Biopsy and MRI findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Paraganglioma

 

Explanation:

The given scenario along with biopsy findings (Zellballen patterns) and MRI appearance (salt and pepper) supports the diagnosis of Paraganglioma or Glomus tumour.

 

Glomus tumor (Paraganglioma)

Definition

Tumors originating from the paraganglia are known as paragangliomas, with glomus tumors being a specific type of paraganglioma.

Tumour type

Benign (most common benign tumor of middle ear)

Origin

Paraganglionic cells or glomus bodies .

Prevalence

Commonly seen in middle-aged individuals (40-50 years), with a higher prevalence in females

Types

  1. Glomus tympanicum: Arise from the promontory of the middle ear (tympanic plexus).
  2. Glomus jugulare: Arises from the dome of the jugular bulb (sympathetic plexus covering the jugular vein).

 

Spread

  • Inferiorly: To the jugular foramen
  • Anteriorly: Invading into the nasopharynx (blockage of eustachian tube)
  • Posteriorly: Invading the mastoid
  • Superiorly: To the posterior and middle cranial fossa (IX-XII cranial nerve palsy)
  • Laterally: To the tympanic membrane (present as a bleeding polyp of the external auditory canal).
  • Medially: Invading the labyrinth and petrous pyramid (dizziness and facial palsy).

 Fig: Spread of Glomus Tumour

Fig: Spread of Glomus Tumour

 

Clinical manifestations
  • Hearing loss (gradually progressive conductive hearing loss)
  • Pulsatile tinnitus (heartbeat like sounds): It is synchronous with pulse and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.
  • Bleeding from ear (profuse bleeding in case of polyp)
  • Dizziness or vertigo and facial paralysis may appear.
  • Symptoms like headache, sweating, palpitation, hypertension, anxiety due to sympathetic excess (catecholamine release)

Histopathology

  • No capsule (locally invasive)
  • HPE reveals Zell Ballen pattern, where epithelioid chief cells and sustentacular supporting cells form clusters (Zell Ballen) encircled by extensive vascular sinusoids.
  • Preoperative biopsy of the tumour is not performed due to the risk of profuse bleeding from its highly vascular thin-walled blood sinusoids and potential injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery.

               Fig: Zell Ballen Appearance of Glomus Tumour

Otoscopy

  • Red reflex through intact tympanic membrane and bulging tympanic membrane (glomus tympanicum).
  • “Rising sun" appearance due to the tumor originating from the floor of middle ear (glomus jugulare).

 

Diagnosis

  • CECT (IOC) shows erosion of the carotico-jugular spine on the diseased side, known as Phelp’s sign.

CT shows enlargement of the left jugular foramen with bone erosion (arrow)

 
  • MRI scan revealed microhemorrhages within the tumor which appear as white and gray dots on MRI, creating a "salt and pepper" appearance.
 

MRI shows a well-defined mass (arrow) in the left jugular foramen. The mass shows a "salt and pepper appearance,

 
  • Angiography is used to identify the arteries supplying the tumor.

Branchial cyst (Option A): Typically presents as a non-pulsatile, nontender, non transilluminant mass asymptomatic neck mass rather than a pulsatile one. It is usually found in the lateral aspect of the neck and does not typically cause red, bulging tympanic membrane or tinnitus.

            Fig: Branchial cyst

 

Tubercular lymph nodes (Option B) result from tuberculosis infection spreading to the lymph nodes. Diagnosis is made through FNAC or biopsy, which reveals granulomatous lesions. Acid-fast bacilli (AFB) may be present, and cultures can determine drug sensitivity, especially in multidrug-resistant cases.

             Fig: Tubercular lymph nodes

 

Thymic cyst (Option C) are located in the anterior mediastinum, show homogeneous fluid density on imaging. It is often asymptomatic but can cause symptoms if it grows large enough to compress adjacent structures and do not present with pulsatile tinnitus.

                Fig: Thymic cyst

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with progressive hearing loss, ear fullness, and occasional tinnitus in her right ear, as well as a faint pulsating sound when lying down. During otoscopy, pressure applied with a Siegel speculum causes the tumor to vibrate vigorously and then blanch. Which sign does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Brown sign

 

Explanation:

The given scenario is a case of glomus tumour describing the Brown sign or Pulsating sign.

 

Signs of Glomus Tumour

Pulsation sign or Brown sign

(Option D)

When ear canal pressure is increased with Siegel's speculum, the tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches; the opposite occurs when the pressure is released.

Aquinos sign

(Option A)

Applying pressure to the neck compresses the internal carotid artery, reducing blood flow to the ascending pharyngeal artery and the tumor. This results in a color change of the tumor from red to pale during otoscopic examination as the blood supply diminishes.

Phelps sign

(Option B)

In a CECT scan, the carotico-jugular spine (a dense bony structure between the jugular vein and the mastoid process) remains intact on the unaffected side. On the affected side, erosion of this spine is observed.

CT shows enlargement of the left jugular foramen with bone erosion (arrow)

Salt pepper appearance

In an MRI scan, microhemorrhages within the tumor are identified as white and gray speckles, creating a characteristic "salt-and-pepper" appearance.

MRI shows a well-defned mass (arrow) in the left jugular foramen. The mass shows a "salt and pepper appearance,

Rising sun appearance (Option C)

In glomus jugulare tumor, otoscopy may reveal a "rising sun" appearance when the tumor originates from the floor of the middle ear.

On otoscopic examination, the jugulotympanic glomus tumor appears as a reddish tumor formation highlighted by the transparency of the tympanic membrane, the so-called “rising sun” sign.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with progressive hearing loss in his right ear over the past year, accompanied by a sensation of fullness and occasional tinnitus. Examination shows a pulsatile neck mass, and radiology reveals a 5 cm tumour located below the right middle ear. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Both A and B

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is diagnosed as a glomus tumor with pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss and pulsatile mass in the neck, which is managed by Embolization followed by surgical excision.

 

Management of glomus tumor

Surgical excision: Mostly surgical excision is the treatment of choice in glomus tumors and it consists of

Transcanal Approach

For a localized glomus tympanicum tumor where the entire circumference of the tumor is visible.

Hypotympanic Approach

For tumors limited to the promontory and hypotympanum, a superiorly based tympanomeatal flap is elevated via a postauricular approach, and the bony inferior tympanic ring is drilled to expose the tumor's lower margin

Extended Facial Recess Approach

It is used for small glomus tympanicum tumors extending into the mastoid but not reaching the jugular bulb. For more extensive cases, a modified radical mastoidectomy is performed.

Mastoid-Neck Approach

This technique is used for glomus jugulare tumors that do not extend into the internal carotid artery, posterior cranial fossa, or neck.

Infratemporal Fossa Approach (Fisch)

It is employed for large glomus jugulare tumors.

Transcondylar Approach

Used for tumors extending to the foramen magnum, often recurrent glomus jugulare tumors, it provides access to the craniocervical junction and exposes the occipital condyle and jugular tubercle
  • Embolization is used to reduce tumor vascularity before surgery or as the sole treatment for inoperable patients who have already undergone radiation.

 

  • Radiation (Option C) does not cure the tumor but can reduce its vascularity and halt growth. It is used for inoperable tumors, residual or recurrent tumors after surgery, and for older patients where extensive skull base surgery is unsuitable.

questions.text: According to Fisch's classification of glomus tumors, tumors with intracranial invasion measuring less than 2 cm are classified under which type?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Type D1

Explanation:

According to Fisch’s classification, the tumors with intracranial invasion of less than 2 cm are categorized under Type D1.

Fisch’s classification for glomus tumors

Type A

Tumours restricted to middle ear (Glomus tympanicum tumour)

Type B

Tumours restricted to tympanomastoid site

Type C

Tumours involving the infra-labyrinth portion towards the petrous apex

Type D1

Tumour with intracranial invasion (<2cm)

Type D2

Tumour with intracranial invasion (>2cm)
